Key Arguments: The bill imposes extreme restrictions on free speech and public debate.
Historical examples from the Soviet Union, Cuba, and North Korea show the negative consequences of censorship.
The definition of harm is too broad and lacks clarity on who decides what constitutes harm.
Misinformation can originate from official sources, making censorship problematic.
Exclusion of government, news sources, and educational institutions from the bill is inconsistent if speech is truly harmful.
The bill could hinder political debate and the free contest of ideas.
Main Themes: Broad and unclear definitions of harm
Potential bias and inconsistency in application
Notable Quotes: The harm caused by not allowing free contest of ideas is far greater than any harm that can be caused by so called misinformation and disinformation.
I cannot believe that a Bill like this one can even be considered in a free and democratic society.
The right to free speech is one of the basic human rights in a democratic society.
